newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: INTERVIEW-WasteMan to be debt-free in 1997.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW-WasteMan to be debt-free in 1997.

text.p: Waste Management NZ Ltd should be almost debt free by the end of 1997, Chief Executive Kim Ellis said in an interview.

Commenting on Waste Management's strong balance sheet, Ellis said: "We are getting caught up with EVA (economic value added) at the moment and we will be almost debt-free by the end of next year at the rate we are going, which just does not work on an EVA model."
Waste Management NZ is 60 percent owned by Waste Management International Plc (WMI), which in turn is 80 percent owned by WMX Technologies Inc in the United States.
Ellis said it did not appear likely that WMI's level of ownership would change.
While remaining listed in New Zealand did have its costs, there were benefits in terms of being able to attract a higher standard of management and a higher profile generally.
It also enabled a degree of independence from the parent.
But Ellis agreed that, with such a high proportion of the stock tied up by WMI, illiquidity was a problem.
This had been partly addressed by a recent two-for-one bonus issue and a sell-down by one of the company's major individual shareholders.
"There is a lot more liquidity now in terms of spread of institutional interest than there was two years ago, but it's still not as liquid as it could be," he said.

"The directors are more aware of this issue and have a little more confidence about dealing with it. So that's another component of strategy that has to be considered. We should be carrying some debt."
Ellis said some form of capital repayment was an option "or spending a lot of money somewhere".
While Redvale landfill in Auckland had taken up NZ$40 million and more than four years to develop, the company was still cash positive at the end of every year.
Waste Management was enjoying a "modestly good year" along similar lines to the first half to June, when it made a NZ$3.27 million profit, up nine percent on the same period a year ago.
